channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump’s Security Strategy Focuses on Profit, Not Spreading Democracy
item.description: President Trump’s new National Security Strategy describes a country that is focused on doing business and reducing migration while avoiding passing judgment on authoritarians.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House last month. The National Security Strategy his administration released describes a world in which American interests are far narrower than how prior administrations — even in his first term — had portrayed them.

item.title: U.S. Warns of Europe’s ‘Civilizational Erasure’ Through Immigration
item.description: America’s goal should be “to help Europe correct its current trajectory,” the administration said in its new National Security Strategy.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Jeanna Smialek and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: President Trump has made no secret of his disdain for the political leadership in Europe.

item.title: Supreme Court Agrees to Review Trump Order Restricting Birthright Citizenship
item.description: The administration asked the justices to uphold an executive order ending birthright citizenship after lower courts ruled it violated the Constitution.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court earlier this month.

item.title: The Supreme Court, Once Wary of Partisan Gerrymandering, Goes All In
item.description: The court’s conservative majority said that Texas’ asserted political motives justified letting the state use voting maps meant to disadvantage Democrats in the midterms.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:description: A map of Texas’ congressional districts during a hearing in Austin in August.

item.title: Frank Gehry, the Disrupter, Opened Their Imaginations
item.description: Architects, artists, clients and partners assess his life and impact over eight decades.
item.dc:creator: Sam Lubell
item.media:description: Frank Gehry in 1988 in front of his famed Santa Monica, Calif., house, its Dutch Colonial core wrapped with a combination of chain-link fencing, corrugated metal, and off-kilter windows and beams.

item.title: Frank Gehry, Titan of Architecture, Is Dead at 96
item.description: He burst onto the scene with an attention-getting renovation of his Southern California home before going on to design some of the world’s most recognizable buildings.
item.dc:creator: Nicolai Ouroussoff
item.media:description: Frank Gehry en 2003, en una ceremonia de inauguración de la Sala de Conciertos Walt Disney de Los Ángeles, uno de los muchos edificios célebres que diseñó en todo el mundo.

item.title: Frank Gehry: 12 Essential, Stunning Projects
item.description: A singular genius, Gehry redefined architecture with joyful buildings like the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles and the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman
item.media:description: The Guggenheim Museum Bilbao in Spain is a game-changing, fish-shaped art museum on the waterfront.

item.title: Running Out of Time, Republicans in Congress Still Lack a Health Plan
item.description: Top Republicans have said they want to produce a proposal in short order to counter Democrats pressing for an extension of health care subsidies. They have not gotten far.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:description: Senator Tim Scott at the Capitol earlier this year.

item.title: As Bongino Celebrates Arrest in Pipe Bomb Case, Others on the Right Remain Skeptical
item.description: Some activists have lashed out, in a reprise of the backlash over the unsuccessful effort by Trump appointees to shut down the Epstein investigation.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Dan Bongino, the F.B.I.’s deputy director, has alienated some inside the White House with his confrontational, self-promotional approach.

item.title: C.D.C. Vaccine Committee Ends Recommendation That All Newborns Receive Hepatitis B Shots
item.description: In a move toward Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s goal of upending vaccine policy, the committee recommended delaying the shots for infants whose mothers test negative for the virus.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Dr. Robert Malone, the panel’s vice chair, addressing the meeting of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices to discuss the childhood vaccine schedule, at the C.D.C. in Atlanta on Friday.

item.title: Biden Slams Republicans for Using L.G.B.T.Q. Identity as ‘Political Football’
item.description: The former president defended his support for transgender rights, a stance that has provoked second-guessing among some Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. received an award from the LGBTQ+ Victory Institute on Friday in Washington.

item.title: Rich New Yorkers Threaten to Leave. Then They Find Out How Hard That Is.
item.description: Tax accountants and lawyers detail the arduous process wealthy New Yorkers would have to face to avoid paying New York State and city taxes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark S. Klein, left, and Timothy P. Noonan both advise high-net-worth New Yorkers on how to claim tax residency outside New York City.

item.title: Survivors of the Deadly Hong Kong Fire Are in Limbo
item.description: Hong Kong, with some of the world’s highest housing costs and inequality, must now figure out how to help thousands of residents who lost friends, family and homes.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Theodora Yu and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Wang Fuk Court, a residential estate in the Tai Po district of Hong Kong, after a blaze damaged the complex late last month.

item.title: Lots of Oil, Little Production: What to Know About Venezuelan Energy
item.description: The South American country increasingly at odds with the Trump administration has the world’s largest oil reserves.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott and Lazaro Gamio
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: Netflix to Buy Warner Bros in $83 Billion Deal
item.description: The deal to acquire the Hollywood behemoth’s television and film studios as well as HBO Max will bulk up the world’s biggest paid streaming service.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes, Lauren Hirsch and Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Netflix has never tried an acquisition even remotely close to this size.

item.title: Netflix Changes Course Again With Warner Bros. Deal
item.description: The streaming giant has changed its strategy many times over the years. But the decision to get deeply into theatrical releases may be the most startling yet.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Carl Godfrey; Source Photographs via Getty

item.title: San Diego Agrees to Pay $30 Million to Family of Konoa Wilson, Teen Killed by Police
item.description: Konoa Wilson was 16 when he was fatally shot. The settlement, one of the largest in a police killing, surpasses the $27 million paid to the family of George Floyd.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango

item.title: How Batteries Got Cheaper and Made the Electric Grid More Reliable
item.description: An early grid battery was installed in the Atacama Desert in Chile 15 years ago. Now, as prices have tumbled, they are increasingly being used around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Employees working on battery units at the solar project, which is owned by AES, a Virginia company that holds utilities and power plants across the world.

item.title: How Kit Kat Was Killed: Video Shows What a Waymo Couldn’t See
item.description: Surveillance video shows a woman crouching beside a Waymo self-driving taxi, trying to lure a beloved neighborhood cat to safety. A second later, the car drove off.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight

item.title: Trump’s Immigration Crackdown Could Be Illegal
item.description: Once nativism escalates, it’s hard to stop.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Frost
item.media:credit: Will Matsuda for The New York Times

item.title: Actually, the Supreme Court Has a Plan
item.description: We are seeing an intentional effort from justices to rebalance the separation of powers in the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Isgur

item.title: Olivia Nuzzi and Vanity Fair Will Part Ways
item.description: Condé Nast, the magazine’s parent company, said her contract would expire at the end of the year.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa
item.media:description: New claims about Olivia Nuzzi, who was named Vanity Fair’s West Coast editor in September, have arisen over her past relationship with Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

item.title: China’s Mad at Japan, and Pop Stars Are Paying for It
item.description: Beijing is curbing Japanese movies, music and art as it seeks to punish Tokyo for its support of Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Hisako Ueno

item.title: Man Accused of Setting Subway Rider on Fire Is Charged With Arson
item.description: The victim was sleeping on a train at Penn Station in Manhattan around 3 a.m. Monday when an 18-year-old man set him on fire, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Camille Baker
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The man who was set on fire was taken to the hospital in critical condition, according to a criminal complaint from federal prosecutors.

item.title: At the National Archives, a Deep Dive Into the American Story
item.description: A new $40-million exhibit, opening nine months after President Trump fired the chief archivist, uses technology to explore the 13 billion-plus items in its vaults.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The opening gallery of “The American Story,” which features the 1823 copperplate engraving of the Declaration of Independence in one case and, beyond it, a handwritten copy of the Emancipation Proclamation.
